utterances: (Soundbite of laughter)
I was watching TV late at night and I said, why don't I check out ""The Tonight Show""?
And I clicked over and Johnny said something about, we're going to bring out this singer.
Everything about her is thirty-ish.
And you came out and you sang your '30s songs, and you had that long dress on.
You had long, dark hair.
And then you sat down and you gave just as good as you got.
You went toe-to-toe with Johnny Carson.
It was just a wonderful show.
I just - you made a remark about your manager getting you a great room at the Wye, I think.
But that pales in comparison to what I just listened, and when I watched you on the last appearance of Johnny on ""The Tonight Show,"" in the most sincere, loving thank you that you sang to him.
You are at the top of my list for class act.
I've never seen anything like it, and I just wanted to let you know that.
Thank you so much.
Thank you.
That's lovely.
Yeah, it is.
It's lovely.
That appearance on Carson, that last one, got you not only the Emmy, I think that put you in a new place, I think, in a lot of people's minds.
You know, I think perhaps you're right.
I remember being kind of stunned that I wound up to be the one who was the last one.
And I - it was something that I couldn't really think about too much because it would have been so frightening.
But I adored him and he was so supportive.
I mean, even in the earliest, darkest days of my career, I mean, he saw - I think he saw what I could have become.
And he sort of, you know, brought me along until I became what it was that he imagined I could be.
And so I, of course, was very happy to be, you know, to repay that debt.
And I'm very touched by - I was very touched by the outpouring of, you know, really love that I received after doing that for him.
I think that they felt I gave him the sendoff that he deserved.
Let's get Ken on the line.
And Ken's with us from Fort Myers, in Florida.
Hello.
Hello, Bette.
Hello.
I just wanted to say hello because I haven't talked to you since 1971, when I was a young man.
My claim to fame is that I sang with you at the Continental.
You were asking for some volunteers from the audience, and we sang ""Teenager in Love."" And after that I saw you in Buffalo at the Kleinhans Music Hall.
And after that I saw you in Philadelphia in the Clams on the Half Shell Review and in the detour in Fairmount Park.
Then I moved to Florida.
Well, it's nice to hear your voice again.
Are you still a teenager in love?
Yes.
Yeah.
That's good to hear.
We went down on one knee and sang wop, wop, wop.
(Soundbite of laughter)
And you were gorgeous.
Thank you.
Thanks very much.
I'm sure she still is.
I hope so.
Ken, thanks very much.
OK.
Thank you.
Bye.
Ken, of course, is hardly the only person to sing with Bette Midler in the early '70s.
She formed a background group called the Harlettes.
And here they are singing the ""Lullaby of Broadway.
(Soundbite of ""Lullaby of Broadway"")
(Singing) Come on along and listen to, the lullaby of Broadway.
The hip hooray and bally hoo, the lullaby of Broadway.
The rumble of the subway train, the rattle of the taxis.
The daffy-dills who entertain, at Angelo's and Maxie's.
When a Broadway baby says ""Good night,"" it's early in the morning.
Manhattan babies don't sleep tight until the dawn.
Good night, baby, good night, milkman's on his way.
Sleep tight, baby,
Of course, Bette Midler with the ""Lullaby Broadway,"" with the backup singing group, the Harlettes, the roster of singers in that group ever-changing.

Past Harlettes include Melissa Manchester and Katey Sagal, probably best known as the star of the show ""Married with Children."" Bette Midler, the people who come to your show, sometimes they're looking at the backup singers, too.
I hope so!
I hope so.
I'm not paying them top dollars so people won't look at them.
(Soundbite of laughter)
You pay them top dollar?
I pay them medium-sized top dollar, you know, like at the bottom end of the top dollar.
But they are - I'm always very careful about who I get because they take a lot of the weight off my shoulders, you know.
They don't have to just look at me.
The audience doesn't have to just look at me.
They can look at - you know, there's plenty to look at.
And I like to provide that for them.
Because you know, it's hard to be, to stand - for people to just sit there, to pay a ticket price and then sit there and watch just one thing all night long.
I like to have a lot of activity on the stage.
I like to have surprises.
I like to have really good dancing and tremendous costuming and wonderful lights because you know, because it's an experience.
My shows are not just concerts.
They're not - I don't take myself as seriously as maybe I ought to but I'm very, very serious about what I give my audiences.
And I think that the theatrical experience can be so fantastic.
It can - it really can change your life if you - I mean, because I've seen, my life was changed when I saw Janis Joplin.
My life was changed when I saw Tina Turner.
My life was just, you know, turned upside down by those performers.
And I believe, I honestly do believe that people's lives can be transformed by these shows.
So I try to give them a lot, you know.
So they have something to talk about, something for them to be cheerful about for a couple of weeks.
Let's talk with Michael.
Michael with us from Reno, in Nevada.
Reno, boy.
I got a lot of people going to Reno.
How about Vegas?
Do I have anybody coming to Vegas?
Welcome to Las Vegas.
I was wondering if you could talk about - there's another performer on the strip, the ""Divine Mr. M."" Manilow's just down the street down from you.

And it's kind of - I thought it would be interesting if you could talk about your relationship with Barry, since the two of you, really, from the Continental Baths to producing albums, and now both of you are the king and queen of Las Vegas.
Are you planning on maybe dropping in and saying hello?
Well, you know, I went to see his show a couple of years ago, and it was terrific.
And I haven't had the opportunity to see his show since I got there.
I got there on the 20th of January and I never left the building until I got out of the - until my show was over, until my four weeks were over.
And I think, unfortunately, that's kind of the way it works there.
You have to work really, really hard.
I mean, my day starts as soon as I get out of bed.
I, you know, wind up on the treadmill and I, you know, have to answer the mail.
And I have to - it's a full, 12-hour day.
And at the end of 12 hours, all you can do is, you know, have a shot of whiskey and lie down.
It's pretty severe.
And he, I think, goes home every night.
I heard that through the grapevine that he was going home every night.
So I hope to catch him while I'm there, and I'm sure he has every intention of catching me.
Well, congratulations to both of you.
Thank you.
Thanks for the call, Michael.
It sounds like you're the hardest working woman in show business.
You know what, I'll tell you something strange.
I didn't - the stage is 120 feet long.
And you have to - you run from side to side all night long.
And I didn't expect that it was going to be such a workout.
And I mean, I have to run in order to keep my voice.
And so I do run, I do that run.
But then once you get on the stage you're running for 90 minutes, as well.
And it's really pretty intense.

You know, I thought it was going to be - I see a lot of kids out there in Las Vegas and they take it very casually, but because I'm the kind of person I am, I take it quite seriously that it has to be as good as it can possibly get.
So my kids and I, we work really hard.
We rehearse almost every day.
And we do the sound check every single day.
We - it's a good 12-hour day.
And it shows.
I think the audiences have been so responsive because it's really - it's quite slick, I have to say.
And I've very proud of it.
Are you up for this 100 nights a year?
I have - I can do this with my eyes closed.
I mean, my shows are usually two and a-half hours long, so for me to do a 90-minute show is like, oh, my God, I'm on a holiday!
You know, it's like it's a resort town and we are doing basically half of what we usually have to do.
So for us it's like a thrill, you know.
But it still has to be, you know, it has to be really good.
It has to be perfect and it has to be mesmerizing.
And so - and in order for it to look easy, you have to work very hard.
And that's what we do.
Let's get Robby on the line.
Robby's with us from Napa, in California.
Hi, Bette!
Hi!
Thank you so much for such a wonderful career.
You're such a consummate performer.
The first time I saw you was in the very early '80s, maybe '80 or '81 in San Francisco, at the Warfield.
And I thought I was coming to a concert.
I didn't realize I was coming to a real show.
You're such a hard worker, you put out so much to us.
I have so much gratitude to you.
And I wanted to just ask you, in those very early days your shows were different, you know, from your Sophie Tucker jokes, even the Taco joke, and then when you went to Disney, things changed.
I'm wondering if as you're going into Vegas, are you going to bring back some of that spicy show that we used to see a long time ago?
Well, I actually have.
I've done that because I found that - I think that Vegas is - was a real opportunity to be pretty raucous.

I mean, it's the kind of a - it's the - it's a town that needs that, you know, they have got, they had their flirtation with family entertainment, as well, and they decided they'd go back to being Sin City.
And in a funny way, I have decided the same thing.
I mean, I am - I'm very good natured, but I work pretty blue, as they used to say in the old days.
And I'm actually having a great time.
I got all my sequins out, I got all my feathers.
My girls are half-naked, and we are - I have to say, it is ridiculous but it's the only place in the country where people do that.
So I mean, it's their history, it's their tradition, and I fell right into it.
Oh, great.
I think it's fabulous.
I hope you'll bring back Delores Delago at some point...
